results.summary: A garden is opened in memory of a teenage girl who was stabbed to death on a bus in Birmingham.
results.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/b515908c-af8d-9043-b19e-495a022d1e5f"><image id="67904120"/><paragraph role="introduction">A garden in memory of a teenage girl who was stabbed to death on a bus in March has officially opened.</paragraph><paragraph>Christina Edkins, 16, from Birmingham, was attacked on the number nine bus at Five Ways in Edgbaston.</paragraph><paragraph><!-- CPS Asset ID: 24386400 --><link><caption>On Wednesday, Phillip Simelane was detained</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-birmingham-24358473"/></link> under the Mental Health Act after admitting her manslaughter.</paragraph><paragraph>The garden, opened by former England rugby player Phil Vickery, has been built at St Edmund's Catholic Primary in Spring Hill, Birmingham.</paragraph><paragraph>Christina, a former pupil of St Edmund's, was on her way to Leasowes High School in Halesowen to take an exam when she was killed by a single stab wound.</paragraph><paragraph>The head teacher of the high school, Neil Shaw, said if he had the chance to choose the sort of pupil he would like to teach, "[he] would fill the school with Christinas".</paragraph><image id="70258962"/><paragraph>The rugby charity Wooden Spoon gave £8,000 of the £10,000 needed to build the garden in the grounds of the school in Roseberry Street. </paragraph><paragraph>The rest of the money was raised by school pupils and the police.</paragraph><paragraph>Mary O'Friel, head teacher of St Edmund's, said a special Mass had been held with her pupils in memory of Christina.</paragraph><paragraph>"Some of the children have older brothers or sisters who knew Christina, so it is very real to them," she said.</paragraph></body>
results.shortFormBody: <shortFormBody xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/b515908c-af8d-9043-b19e-495a022d1e5f"><paragraph>A garden in memory of a teenage girl who was stabbed to death on a bus in March has officially opened.</paragraph><paragraph>Christina Edkins, 16, from Birmingham, was attacked on the number nine bus at Five Ways in Edgbaston.</paragraph><paragraph>On Wednesday, Phillip Simelane was detained under the Mental Health Act after admitting her manslaughter.</paragraph><paragraph>The garden, opened by former England rugby player Phil Vickery, has been built at St Edmund's Catholic Primary in Spring Hill, Birmingham.</paragraph></shortFormBody>
